title: How to Grow Vegetables in the South (USA)

steps.headline: Start a composting operation the year before, if possible.
steps.description: You can buy compost to nourish your soil and plants, of course, but at-home composting is a great way to save money and use food and yard waste. You can create a pile or use a bin for composting. So long as you create layers of a roughly 60/40 mix of brown (carbon-rich) and green (nitrogen rich) organic material, stir regularly, and keep the compost warm and slightly moist, the pile you start in the fall should be ready to feed your garden by spring.

steps.headline: Find out the average frost dates for your area.
steps.description: The dates for the average last Spring frost and first Autumn frost vary across the U.S. South. The period between these dates is the average outdoor growing season where you live. Consult guides, websites, garden center employees, and neighbors for information specific to where you live. For instance, the first and last frost dates in Raleigh, NC are April 1 and November 4. But they’re March 10 and November 19 in Jackson, MS. Most areas in the South have such long growing seasons that you don’t need to germinate seeds indoors before spring planting. If you do start seedlings inside, be sure to put them in a window that gets at least 6 hours of sunlight every day.

steps.headline: Select your garden site.
steps.description: If possible, choose a location that gets at least 6 hours of sunlight every day. Flat ground is also best, but uneven terrain can work if you terrace you plantings perpendicular to the slope. Pick a site that’s close to an abundant water source. Putting your garden near your home, for instance, will help with watering and make it easier to keep an eye on any plant or weed growth, maintenance needs, and damage.

steps.headline: Test the soil in your preferred garden location.
steps.description: Soils can vary widely in acidity and nutrient levels, and these levels will impact the quality of your garden. You can use home testing kits or probe-style pH testers to get a quick readout, or send samples out to a lab for a more detailed analysis. Every southern state has an agricultural extension program, and the local agents can advise you about unique conditions in your area. They will also test your soil samples so that you can add amendments (fertilizers) to your soil if needed. If you’re a serious home gardener, you should test your soil every year before planting season.

steps.headline: Use raised garden beds if you have very poor soil conditions.
steps.description: It’s fairly easy to make raised garden beds and fill them with an ideal soil mix yourself. Raised beds give you greater control over moisture levels as well, and provide a bit of extra protection against rabbits and other garden invaders. Garden beds shouldn’t be more than 3.5 to 4 feet (1.1 to 1.2 m) wide, or you won’t be able to comfortably reach the plants in the middle.

steps.headline: Make a diagram of your garden on paper before you start digging.
steps.description: Draw a simple sketch of your chosen planting area. This will help you visualize how much you can plant and where you’ll put each plant type. You’ll also get a better idea of how much compost, topsoil, fertilizer, etc., you’ll need. Size your garden based on the number of people who will actively work to maintain it. For a novice veggie gardener working alone, 100 square feet (9.3 square meters) — e.g., a 10 by 10 feet (3.0 by 3.0 m) square — is a good starting point.

steps.headline: Prepare the soil in your garden area.
steps.description: Clear away any rocks or surface obstructions, then use a spade to remove any grass or ground cover. Once cleared, till or hand spade your garden to a depth of 12 to 18 inches (30 to 46 cm). Work in compost and any soil amendments needed (based on your soil testing), and till the soil again to make sure these additions are worked all the way through the soil. For maximum effect, work in fertilizers 10-14 days before planting. Call your local utilities to mark their lines before you start digging.

steps.headline: Sketch on your diagram where you’ll plant your chosen veggies.
steps.description: Choose vegetables that your family likes to eat, not what looks pretty in a gardening magazine. As a beginner, start with 3-5 veggie types. Consult the backs of your seed packages for the length to harvest for each plant. If you plant several rows of carrots, which have a long maturation date, you may not be able to use that space to plant more seeds later in the season. Note which vegetables you want to plant first, as well as where you want to plant successive crops. Consider the mature size of the vegetable. For example, winter squash require a lot of space and cannot be crowded.

steps.headline: Maximize your yield by pairing early- and late-maturing crops.
steps.description: If space is an issue, sketch out a plan for planting early harvest crops alongside late harvest crops. The former will be harvested and gone before the latter are ready to pick. For instance, sow cabbage, carrots, and beets in the same rows as early peas and beans. You can also plant corn in between rows of potatoes, radishes in between rows of lettuce, etc. If space isn’t an issue, keeping early- and late-harvest crops in separate areas will make weeding and harvesting somewhat easier, however.

steps.headline: Use the shade from taller plants to your advantage.
steps.description: On your diagram, figure out the best spots to plant vegetables that prefer cool weather. Some leafy vegetables, like spinach and lettuce, will wilt in full sun. Plant those in rows where they will eventually get some shade from taller vegetables, like tomatoes. If you plant taller crops on the southern edge of your garden plot, they will block more sunlight from reaching nearby shorter crops than if planted on the northern edge. Beyond the first year, your garden will do better if you practice crop rotation — planting different crops in different spots. So consider multiple possible layouts and keep them “on file.”

parts.name: Planting Crops throughout the Growing Season

steps.headline: Create long, low mounds for your rows if the soil drains poorly.
steps.description: If your soil has a high clay content or is in a low-lying area, you’ll want to elevate your planting rows a bit to keep your plants from being over-saturated. The mounds only need to be a few inches/centimeters high. After you’ve cleared the garden plot, keep an eye on it through a few rain showers to see if water tends to puddle or the soil stays mucky. Some plants grow better with higher or lower mounds. Consult the seed packet, a garden center employee, or a gardening expert you know. Essentially, your garden will look like you’ve dug and filled in several long, skinny, shallow graves!

steps.headline: Consult veggie-specific guides for planting depth and spacing.
steps.description: Some seeds should be planted only .25 inches (0.64 cm) deep, while others prefer 3 inches (7.6 cm). The ideal plant spacing varies just as widely. Follow the guidelines on your seed packets or seedling containers for specific guidance for each crop. You can find a detailed planting chart for popular southern veggies at http://www.clemson.edu/extension/hgic/plants/pdf/hgic1256.pdf (Table 2).

steps.headline: Start planting seeds in February or March.
steps.description: The best start date for your planting program will depend on your location in the South. The monthly guide in this section of the current article is a general recommendation for the mid-U.S. South. Also look for guides more specific to where you live, such as in central Georgia (https://secure.caes.uga.edu/extension/publications/files/pdf/C%20943_4.PDF) or central South Carolina (http://www.clemson.edu/extension/hgic/plants/pdf/hgic1256.pdf). In February, you can plant beets. In March, plant any of the following: turnips, Swiss chard, radishes, white potatoes, onions, lettuce, kale, collards, carrots, cabbage

steps.headline: Continue planting in earnest in April and May.
steps.description: While your early season seedlings are sprouting up, you can get started on several other southern garden staples. In April, you can plant summer and winter squash, spinach, corn, broccoli, and pole beans. In May, plant sweet potatoes, peppers, okra, eggplant, cucumbers, and lima beans.

steps.headline: Plant tomatoes and second rounds of other veggies in June and July.
steps.description: With the South’s extended growing season, you can get multiple harvests of several vegetable types, such as pole beans and winter squash. Put your prized tomatoes in the ground in June. In July, you can add pole beans, lima beans, winter squash and pumpkins

steps.headline: Finish the season by planting more of your favorites.
steps.description: Unlike many other parts of the U.S., in much of the South, you can plant in September and still get a robust harvest of certain crops. So go ahead and make use of the whole growing season! In August, plant Brussels sprouts, carrots, broccoli, beets, and kale. September is a good time to plant Swiss chard, onions, turnip, and kale.

steps.headline: Give your garden adequate amounts of water.
steps.description: Rainwater is best because it provides needed nutrients, but rain is unreliable. Most plants, including tomatoes (a southern garden staple), require regular watering but good drainage in order to produce a high yield. Consider saving rainwater in rain barrels so that you can use it throughout the year. Summers in the South can be extremely hot and dry, so water your garden early in the morning while it is a bit cooler. Watering during the hottest part of the day will result in the sun evaporating the moisture that your plants need. Consult watering guides specific to your veggies.

steps.headline: Mulch your garden soon after your sprouts emerge from the soil.
steps.description: Don't wait for weeds to overtake tender sprouts or transplants. Mulching helps the soil stay moist and cool on hot days. Mulching will also help with weed control, and organic mulch will enrich the soil as it decomposes. Don’t overdo the mulch, though. You just need enough to create a thin, fairly uniform layer over the soil.

steps.headline: Protect your crops from animals.
steps.description: You can keep pesky animals out of your veggie garden in a variety of ways. You can use several types of fencing or covers, or use deterrents like sprays or scarecrows. Use trial-and-error to find the combination of defenses that works best against your invaders.

steps.headline: Keep up with watering, weeding, staking, etc.
steps.description: You can’t “plant it and forget it” and expect to have an abundant veggie harvest. Spend a half hour or so every day or two keeping up with your garden maintenance. This is better for your garden (and for you) than having to spend hours pulling weeds that have been left to grow. Pull weeds by pinching the stems right at the soil line and pulling out the entire root structure. This works best with moist soil. When it comes to supporting plants, stake the tomatoes early on, because the branches and the tomatoes get very heavy. Other climbing plants like pole beans need tied to supports because they’ll rot and attract pests if they lay on the ground.

steps.headline: Harvest according to your planting guides and your own eyes.
steps.description: Your planting guide might say that kale takes 50-55 days to reach harvest time, but remember that this is only a rough estimate. When the leaves, beans, or fruits look ripe and ready to eat, they’re ready to pick! Don’t let your juicy tomatoes “wither on the vine” — check regularly and harvest your veggies daily.

steps.headline: Spend the off-season planning next year’s garden.
steps.description: From roughly October through January (depending on your location), don’t just dream about next year’s garden. Instead, create your gardening plan for next year and build up your compost pile. In January, test your soil, till your garden space, and add any soil amendments as needed.
